back: Control surface used to roll the aircraft.
Control surface that controls pitch.
Control surface that controls yaw.
Extendable surfaces that increase lift and drag for landing.
Surfaces that reduce lift and increase drag to help descend or slow down.
Small adjustable surface that helps maintain level flight without constant control input.
The main body of the aircraft that holds crew and passengers.
The tail section of an aircraft providing stability and control.
The compartment where the pilot and co-pilot control the aircraft.
Lever used to control engine power.
Regulates the fuel-to-air ratio in piston engines.
Instrument that measures altitude using air pressure.
Displays the speed of the aircraft relative to the surrounding air.
Shows the aircraft’s orientation relative to the horizon.
Displays the aircraft’s direction relative to magnetic north.
Shows the rate of climb or descent in feet per minute.
Radio device that sends identification and altitude to air traffic control.
Instrument that measures airspeed by sensing air pressure.
Loss of lift due to exceeding the critical angle of attack.
The upward aerodynamic force that opposes weight and allows flight.
